Why University is the Perfect Time to Start A Business

31/05/2013

REDACTED on how an abundance of free time has allowed him to start DenimUmbrella, the web design/media company now paying his food bills.

Image by

By James Bithell

I took a year out before starting at York. I'm hesitant to describe it as a 'gap year', because I did decidedly little in the way of gap year activities: no trekking in Thailand, no paraglading at 'Picchu. None of that stuff. The unfortunate combination of the lack of money and the motivation to get any meant that any soul-searchy travelling was limited to the first few weeks, after which the year quickly descended into the kind of sedentary, meandering hedonism available almost exclusively to those revelling in the twin benefits of being old enough to do what they like and young enough (just) to get away with it. By this I mean that I did nothing for a year. A fun nothing, but a nothing nonetheless.

This temporal void led--as they so often do--to a state of crisis. With university looming, my mind was filled with unsettling notions of stone-set deadlines, of late nights and early mornings devoted to the ever-unsatisfied God-o'-Work. After such an extended period of delicious, unstructured freedom, would the routine demanded by returning to formal education prove too much for my fragile mind? I suppose it remains to be seen, really, but suffice it to say that first year, as we all now know in hindsight, is hardly worth stressing about.

With the recent, rather flaccid attempt at uproar about the scarcity of contact hours within York's academic timetable (presumably under particular fire as it sits neatly in the middle of the Venn diagram depicting 'Low Teaching Times' against 'First Page of The Good University Guide), there's been a lot of discussion about the way in which university can be considered 'value for money', the questionable centrality of teaching time to our conceptions of a 'proper' uni experience, and why, precisely, we ought to care a red-face-inducing amount about those and myriad other aspects of student life. The question of direct value for money, in an objective sense, seems to answer itself. It would be difficult to argue that Â£9000 a year is well-spent on fewer than a hundred contact hours. But the reason that universities are permitted to get away with this flagrant disregard for such things is that we, the students, are on the bad end of a one-sided customer/business relationship.

To most, 'University' demands a capital letter, representing as it does some mythical bastion of arcane knowledge; but to those pulling the financial strings, the student is little more than a customer. In no other field but education would a capitalist society allow for such discrepancies between that which is ventured (a distinctly less-than-casual Â£27,000) and the seemingly arbitrary return. If the same Â£9000 spent elsewhere can provide three times as many teaching hours, something has gone awry. With any luck, this honeymoon period is on the way out and universities are soon to be taken to task over the matter, but until then I'd like to suggest we reframe slightly. Consider your tuition fee as paying for 'the experience', not the contact and, with any luck, you might be able to capitalise on the free time.

First year, as it happens, has been one of the busiest of my life. Just not for the reasons I might have expected. Instead of being swamped too much by the course's workload (magnitudinally less than that of Sixth Form), I've been devoting all of my non-Kuda, non-sleeping hours to DenimUmbrella. (The dream is that, one day, I shan't have to elaborate upon that rather odd name--you'll already have heard of it and be very briefly, very marginally impressed by my involvement--but until then I'll explain a bit further.) DenimUmbrella represents the culmination of just over a year's work and, having launched properly on April 13th (the same day that an elephant first arrived on US soil; 'the more you know...'), it's now a fully-fledged web-design and digital media production company. It feels a lot like I've tricked everyone into thinking I should be allowed to run a business, but so far no one's cottoned on. Just don't tell on me, will you.

We started the business precisely because we were unable to find any web-design companies who seemed to have looked at the abstract notions of 'affordability' and 'quality' and sought to find anything but an extreme position on one (or occasionally both, 1&1) of the above. We'd been shopping around for a website for a (totally separate, definitely pointless) project, and were disappointed to have found that the vast majority either looked awful and were affordable, or weren't affordable and looked, well, for the most part pretty generic. There's a reason companies like Spotify, Apple and, yes, even Google care about good web-design: it can turn a potential client into an actual client, but this rarely seems reflected in the largely-indistinguishable array of small-business and creative-industry websites rolling about the place. Abandoning our previous idea, we decided instead to try our very best to come up with something we'd want to buy. By April 15th, two days after launch, 11 other people decided that they'd like to buy it too. Our media offerings (thus far existing primarily of a rather niche podcast) have an approximate reach of 15,000 listeners an episode, and the business's Facebook and Twitter accounts have already, in a real blow to the ego, become far more popular than I ever will. Such is life.

If it wasn't for the fact that my course offers a relatively large amount of optimistically-entitled 'independent study', I would never have found the time to develop DenimUmbrella beyond a childishly-named pipedream. As it happens, being at university has been directly valuable to my entrepreneurial endeavours in more ways than simply allowing the time to work on a project. York's Enterprise department is not talked about enough for the help it can offer. Within a week of emailing them, I'd been scheduled for an hour's consultation with the Enterprise officer, Jessica Noon, who provided advice, suggested directions and organised several concrete steps in order to further my progress. These included a university-funded meeting with a specialist business advisor, Mike Everitt of Business Support York & North Yorkshire, which again proved utterly invaluable given Mike's wealth of experience and immediately actionable, tailored advice. I realise it seems ostensibly counter-intuitive, but I struggle to think of a more suitable, supportive, environment to pursue one's business ambitions than that which is available when studying for a degree at university, particularly ours. York has its own community of student entrepreneurs, and the Ron Cooke Hub is home to the Student Enterprise Centre for use as professional space and networking with like-minded sorts.

I couldn't begin to argue that Â£9000 a year simply for a degree is money well-spent, but as the job market demands we spend it, we may as well make the most of everything to which attending a university entitles us. There's unlikely to be a better time to realise your ground-up business ideas, so if you have them, I really think now is the time to get them going. And, of course, if you're going to need a website (or just fancy a chat), you know where to find us.
